questions.description: Relationships feel intense and swing between idealizing and devaluing someone.
Fear of abandonment (real or imagined) triggers strong reactions.
Feelings toward someone can change drastically within hours.
Tests others' loyalty or becomes anxious if reassurance is missing.
Feels hurt easily in conflicts and may react abruptly.
Wants closeness quickly but later feels overwhelmed and pulls away.
Engages in impulsive behaviors (spending, sex, substances, binge eating, risky driving).
Acts quickly to reduce distress even when consequences may be negative.
Has thoughts or behaviors of self-harm or suicide during high stress.
Picks fights or arguments when feeling empty or rejected.
Finds it hard to stop actions once angry or upset.
Alternates between intense pursuit and cutting ties after conflict.
Sense of self shifts depending on who you are with.
Frequent feelings of inner emptiness.
Unsure who you are or what you want long-term.
Goals or values change abruptly.
Experiences moments of detachment or unreality under stress.
Feels intense shame or self-hate after emotional episodes.
Mood changes sharply within hours.
Anger can be intense and hard to calm.
Very sensitive to perceived rejection or criticism.
Feels desperate when alone or disconnected from others.
Becomes suspicious or paranoid about others' intentions when stressed.
Recovers slowly after conflicts and keeps ruminating or agitated.

carreras.description: Consistent boundaries and gradual closeness help reduce swings. DBT/mentalization approaches can support relationship stability and fear of abandonment.
Build pause strategies before acting, safety plans for crises, and replace impulsive behaviors with skills. Seek professional help for self-harm or substance risk.
Explore identity with values-based goals and grounding for dissociation. Therapy can help strengthen a stable sense of self.
Emotion-regulation skills (DBT), distress tolerance, and paced breathing can shorten episodes. Clinical support is recommended if intensity disrupts daily life.

labels.HeroSubtitle: Not a diagnosis. Use it to notice patterns and seek professional guidance if needed.
labels.MethodNote: Self-exploration tool. Not diagnostic. Items draw from borderline/DBT-informed psychoeducation to support conversations with a clinician.
labels.MethodSummaryScoring: Percent is based on your "yes" responses per dimension; more "yes" means higher reported frequency.
